conclusion: The light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows on the ground.
Each object casts a shadow (A, B, C, D) based on its shape and the angle of the light.
When the light source moves forward, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes.
This change affects both the position and the size of the shadows.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward.
The size of the shadows will generally increase.
Shadow A will move backward and become larger.
Shadow B will shift backward and increase in size.
Shadow C will move backward and grow larger.
Shadow D will shift backward and expand in size.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move backward and increase in size when the light source moves forward.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become larger.
